items.title: Risking her life, a young Iranian breaks through the blackout with a message for Trump
items.description: From inside Iran, a defiant voice bravely breaks through the internet blackout to detail the horrors she has witnessed and to tell the president of the United States "the people are waiting for America to intervene".

items.title: Best rain in months brings flood threat to eastern and northern Australia
items.description: Severe thunderstorms and flooding rain are expected to ease the short-term fire threat, while Queensland continues to be drenched from ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji.

items.title: Rental market growth stalls, as tenants hit limit of what they can pay
items.description: Australia's rental market is "starting to rebalance" with prices flat in some capital cities but affordability remains a concern, according to Domain, which says an annual salary of $100,000 is needed to live comfortably.

items.title: Greens deal in play as Coalition backs off Labor's hate and gun reforms
items.description: Liberals are backing away from a push to tackle antisemitism with stronger racial hatred laws, with some senior figures in the party also voicing freedom of speech concerns.

items.title: Group that has courted controversy for years defiant over hate speech laws
items.description: Controversial group Hizb ut-Tahrir says the government "cannot ban" its ideas despite its members facing the threat of jail time under proposed hate speech laws to go before parliament.

items.title: Even small improvements in sleep, exercise and veggie intake may help you live longer
items.description: Two new studies have found that small improvements in day-to-day life can have substantial impacts on life expectancy.

items.title: Why climbing ladders can have serious consequences for older Australians
items.description: Thousands of people present to Australian hospitals each year for ladder and roof falls, with doctors urging caution — particularly for ageing Australians.

items.title: Firefighters gain ground across Victoria as damage toll rises
items.description: More than 228 homes have been confirmed destroyed by bushfires across Victoria, with authorities warning the total is likely to rise.

items.title: Live: ACTU signs AI deal with Microsoft to protect workers' rights
items.description: Australia's peak union body moves to shore up creative and media jobs, while the ASX is set to rise marginally after Wall Street slides again. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

items.title: FBI raids home and seizes devices of Washington Post journalist
items.description: The reporter had previously reported on the Trump administration's efforts to fire hundreds of thousands of federal workers.

items.title: The tiny Australian outpost at the 'bottom of the world'
items.description: From 6,000 applications each year, only about 300 make the cut to travel down to Antarctica and experience a workplace like no other.

items.title: Denmark 'agrees to disagree' with US over Greenland's future
items.description: The United States and Denmark continue to disagree over the future of Greenland after a meeting at the White House amid ongoing threats from President Donald Trump threatening to seize the semi-autonomous Danish territory for national security reasons.

items.title: US to suspend immigrant visa processing from 75 countries
items.description: The US State Department will suspend processing of immigrant visas for people from 75 countries, including Brazil, Thailand, Somalia and Afghanistan, from January 21.

items.title: Australian champ vows to finish Dakar with broken collarbone, sternum
items.description: Daniel Sanders says he has broken his collarbone and sternum in a crash on stage 10 of the Dakar Rally, but vows to finish the last three stages.

items.title: Families warn of risks after hiring au pairs through social media
items.description: Families who turned to social media to find an au pair say the lack of safeguards left them vulnerable to serious problems.

items.title: Why the Iranian government doesn't want you to see this film
items.description: Would you face prison for what you believe in? Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi already has and, following the release of his latest film, he may again.

items.title: SA Premier attempts to distance himself from a crisis engulfing 'The Festival State'
items.description: After backing the Adelaide Festival’s decision to drop a Palestinian Australian author from Writers’ Week, Premier Peter Malinauskas is now trying to distance himself from a crisis that threatens to do untold damage to South Australia’s festival reputation.

items.title: Majority of NT Aboriginal justice groups yet to emerge as deadline looms
items.description: Despite the NT government signing on to establish 20 Aboriginal Law and Justice Groups by 2027, just five are up and running with less than 12 months to go.

items.title: 'No joke, London Bridge has fallen down': The moment two tourists were trapped by nature
items.description: Kelli Bryers wasn't sure if anyone had seen the London Bridge rock formation collapse just seconds after she and her cousin, David Darrington, had crossed it.

items.title: Captured tobacco kingpin thought 'he was out of reach', says Burke
items.description: Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke says he believes tobacco kingpin Kaz Hamad thought he was "out of reach" of authorities before his arrest in Iraq.

items.title: X to change AI chatbot after outrage over sexual deepfake images
items.description: New laws in the UK that would outlaw the generation of sexual deepfakes are set to come into force this week.

items.title: Community's days of driving eight hours for a GP appointment now gone
items.description: Gulgong went 18 months without a GP clinic. It has now reopened, giving residents a reprieve from travelling hundreds of kilometres to see a doctor.

items.title: 'She watches a lot more cricket than I do': Healy taken aback by commentary praise
items.description: After calling time on her decorated 15-year career, a spell in media commentary looks inevitable for Australian cricket star Alyssa Healy.

items.title: 'Can't speak': Tennis battler beats the pros to take home $1 million jackpot
items.description: Sydneysider Jordan Smith has beaten grand slam champion Jannik Sinner and dual grand slam finalist Amanda Anasimova to take home the prize in the novelty format.

items.title: Tree bark captures and eliminates harmful greenhouse gases
items.description: Tiny, gas-eating microbes hidden in the bark of trees offer scientists a crucial clue in the fight against global warming.
